The premise is: "If the dog was inside, then the cat was outside."
The conclusion is: "If the dog was not inside, then the cat was not outside."

This argument form is known as the contrapositive. The contrapositive of the statement "If P, then Q" is "If not Q, then not P."

In this case, the premise is "If the dog was inside, then the cat was outside," which can be expressed as "If P, then Q." The conclusion is the contrapositive of this statement, which is "If the dog was not inside, then the cat was not outside."

The contrapositive is a logically valid form of argument. If the premise is true, then the conclusion must also be true.
